loans.name: Alba Luz

texts.es:
La Sra. Alba es trabajadora del centro de insumos para la salud en el departamento de Limpieza.
Alba  va usar el crédito para Compra de  perlines, clavos y zinc.
Ella quiere cambiar una parte del techo por lo que este se encuentra en mal estado.
Ella  es madre soltera de cuatro hijos dos de ellos están casado y dos están en la universidad.
Este es el segundo crédito que Perla ha tenido con CEPRODEL. 
Ha trabajado con ceprodel 20 meses.
Alba dijo que sus créditos con Ceprodel le han ayudado mucho por lo que ha venido mejorando su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Alba works in the housekeeping department of the health supply center. She will use the funds to buy zinc metal sheeting, edging and nails. She wants to replace part of her roof because it is poor condition. She is a single mother of four children, two of whom are married and two are university students. This is her second loan with CEPRODEL; she has collaborated with CEPRODEL for 20 months. Alba said that Ceprodel loans have helped her much with her home improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc metal sheeting, edging, nails.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gregoria's Group

texts.en: Gregoria B. is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Gregoria is from the village of Villa Nuesa. She is 57 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Gregoria owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Gregoria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Gregoria is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: María Emilia

texts.es:
La Sra. María F. vende gaseosa, jugos y agua helada en la terminal de buses inter-locales que viajan al departamento de León ubicada en el mercado Israel lewite en Managua.
María va usar el crédito para comprar gaseosa, jugos y galletas para incrementar su inventario.
Su negocio comenzó cuando María empezó a vender ambulante verduras en el mercado.
María ha tenido su propio lugar en la cotran del mercado para 6 años. Trabaja cada día de 7 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde.
Ella espera que con este financiamiento su negocio crezca mas y a si poder invertir en otros productos.
 María es  casada y con dos hijos los dos en edad escolar.
Este es el octavo crédito que María ha tenido con CEPRODEL. 
Ha trabajado con ceprodel 2 años.
María dijo que sus créditos con Ceprodel le han ayudado mucho por lo que su negocio se mantenido y este esta mas solido.
texts.en:
María F. sells soft-drinks, juices, and cold water at the inter-urban bus station, which is located in the Israel Lewite market in Managua, for buses that go to the department of León, . María will use the funds to buy soft-drinks, juices, and cookies to enlarge her inventory. Her business began when she started to peddle vegetables in the market. She has had her own stall in the bus station in the market for the last 6 years. She works daily from 7am until 6pm. She hopes this funding will help her business grow so that she can stock a greater variety of products. María is married and has two, school-age children. This is María's 8th loan with CEPRODEL; she has collaborated with Ceprodel for two years. María stated that Ceprodel loans have helped her a lot to maintain and strenghten her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft-drinks, juices and cookies.

loans.name: Evelyn's Group

texts.en: Evelyn P. is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Evelyn is from the village of Barangay Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Evelyn owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 7th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Girasoles Group

texts.es:
El grupo Girasoles está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras ellas son Patricia del Carmen G., Bismar de Jesús C. H. y Ana Cristina T.. Ellos son de Nindirí donde cada rincón de este pintoresco municipio está impregnado con la historia de nuestros ancestros desde la época precolombina.

Patricia del Carmen G. desde hace cuatro años vende ropa usada, ella comenzó siendo vendedora ambulante actualmente ideo improvisar en el porche de su casa un pequeño caramanchel para ofertar su producto. Pero esta joven de 28 años trabaja arduamente con la meta de  en tener una tienda adecuada para su negocio. 

Sus compañeros de Bismar de Jesús C. H. y Ana Cristina T. también comercializan ropa de manera ambulante ellos invertirán el crédito en la compra de mercadería en ropa especialmente uniformes que es lo que más se comercializa en está época.
texts.en:
The Girasoles group is made up of three hard-working, enterprising people: Patricia del Carmen G., Bismar de Jesús C. H. & Ana Cristina T.. They are from Nindirí whose every nook and cranny of this picturesque town is infused with the history of our ancestors back to pre-Columbian times. Patricia del Carmen G. has sold used clothing for the last four years. She began as a peddler but now has improvised a small, covered shed on her porch from which to offer her wares. This young, 28-year-old, woman works hard with the goal in sight to have her own well-equipped store. Her collegues Bismar de Jesús C. H. and Ana Cristina T. also are used clothing peddlers; they will use the funding to buy stock merchandise, especially school uniforms, which are big sellers this time of year.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bundles of clothing.

loans.name: Jardines De Paz Group

texts.es:
El grupo Jardines de Paz está integrado por Milagros del Socorro P. J., Felipina de los Ángeles V. y Alba Luz Pavón tres féminas esforzadas y trabajadoras que salen a recorrer las calles con sus productos bajo el calor incesante.

La señora Milagros del Socorro P. J. a pesar de tener 66 años ella asegura que se siente como si tuviera 20 años con toda la energía parta seguir trabajando. Está señora vende ropa y zapatos e invertirá el crédito en uniformes es colares ya que en está época es lo que mayormente se comercializa.

Felipina de los Ángeles V. de 39 años de edad desde tempranas horas empieza a palmear las primeras tortillas y poco apoco sus clientes empiezan a llegar por este necesario bastimentó de la dieta nicaragüense.  Mientras Alba Luz Pavón vende ropa interior desde hace cuatro años.
texts.en:
The Jardines de Paz ("Gardens of Peace") group is made up of Milagros del Socorro P. J., Felipina de los Ángeles V. and Alba Luz Pavón -- three dynamic and hard-working women who go out on the streets to sell their products in the relentless heat. Although Milagros del Socorro P. J. is 66 years old, she insists that she feels as if she were 20, and she is filled with energy to continue working. She sells clothing and shoes, and she will invest the loan in school uniforms, since they are the best-selling item at this time of year. Felipina de los Ángeles V. is 39 years old; early in the morning she starts preparing handmade tortillas, and gradually her customers begin to arrive for this necessary component of the Nicaraguan diet. Mientras Alba Luz Pavón has sold undergarments for the past four years.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
Betty A. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 49 years old. Betty is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is A.'s Group.

Betty is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Betty joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Betty is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Betty from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Onon

texts.en: Onon is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent. His older son and daughter, 10 and 9 years old, attend a local secondary school while the younger daughter, 1, stays at home with Onon's wife. He operates a business selling groceries and dairy products door-to-door in his town. He has a car, which he uses to deliver his products to his customers. He started his business in 2000 with working capital of 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD). At first, he used to drive a motorcycle to transport his customer's products. Over the years, he stabilized his business and enabled himself to buy a car. Now his working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD). He is quite knowledgeable in conducting his business and says, "My business goal is to provide quality products on time." He is requesting a 2,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase grocery products and clothes to sell to the province residents.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products and clothes

loans.name: Saijirmaa

texts.en: Saijirmaa is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in a house in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. Her sons, 14 and 12, both attend a local high school while her husband helps with the family business when he isn't driving his taxi. Saijirmaa operates a dairy products retail business out of a rented stall at a local market. She started her business in 2001 with working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD). Since then she has stabilized her business and bought a car with her earnings in order to help her husband to start a taxi service. Now her working capital reached 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD). She is quite an energetic lady who works hard to achieve her goals. She says, "I want to continue to maintain my business in the future." She is requesting a 1,800,000-tugrug loan to purchase variety of dairy products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of dairy products

loans.name: Davaajav

texts.en: T. Davaajav is a 46-year-old single mother who lives with her two sons in the province of Arkhangai in central Mongolia. They live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". Her oldest son is 17 years old and is a university student. Her youngest is 14 years old and attends a local secondary school. Davaajav operates a dairy product trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town. She started her business in 2000 with capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD) and has built a stable operation over the years. She has worked hard to grow her business and has been able to save money for her children's education. Today her working capital exceeds 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD). Davaajav is optimistic about the future and has many plans for her business. She says, "With my business profits I hope to buy a house in the future." She is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~210 USD) loan to purchase a variety of dairy products to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of dairy products to sell.

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en:
T. Munhtsetseg is 31 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her husband is a herder and her 5-year-old daughter hasn't yet started school.

Munhtsetseg operates a milk and dairy product trading business out of a rented stall at a market in her town. She obtains her products from countryside residents and transports them to the province’s capital city to sell.

Munhtsetseg started her business in 2006 with capital of 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD). Since starting her business she has gained much experience and has built a good reputation among her customers and suppliers. Today her working capital has reached 1,200,000 tugrugs (~840 USD).

Munhtsetseg is working hard to grow and improve her business. She says, "I want to save money for my daughter's future." She is requesting a 1,800,000 tugrug loan to purchase dairy products to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products to sell

loans.name: Manuel Salvador

texts.es: El señor Manuel Salvador  N. L. de 54 años desde su niñez  trabajo junto con su padre en la industria de almidón de yuca la cual heredo y piensa heredar a sus hijos tres hijos quienes trabajan con él. Este señor por medio de los préstamos ha ido mejorando su negocio y con el préstamo desea seguir adelante con su pequeña industria.
texts.en:
Manuel Salvador N. L. is 54 years old and works with his father in the cassava starch industry, a business he inherited and plans to pass down to his three children who work with him. Manuel has improved his business thanks to the loans he's received, and with the current one he is requesting he plans to keep making headway with his small plant.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cassava

loans.name: Tumurchudur

texts.en: B. Tumurchudur operates a business making wood products in his town with the help of his wife. He is 26 years old and lives with his wife and baby daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family are temporarily living in a house that has been provided by his sister. Tumurchudur started his business in 2002 with capital of 100,000 tugrugs (~$70 US) after being trained in his craft. Over the years, Tumurchudur has worked hard to expand and improve his business. His earnings have enabled him to build a workshop and purchase woodworking tools and equipment. Today his working capital exceeds 800,000 tugrugs (~$560 US). Tumurchudur is a hardworking man with good communication skills. He says, "My main goal is to deliver quality product to my customers." He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase wood to fill current orders.

loans.use: To purchase unprocessed wood

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en: G. Tungalag is 37 years old and lives with her parents in a house in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. Both of her parents are retired. She operates a clothing trading business out of a rented stall at a local market. Tungalag started her business in 2008 and has established herself well in the local business community over the last year and a half. With her hard work, she has increased her working capital to a level exceeding 1,250,000 tugrugs (~880 USD). Tungalag has many plans for the future and is working diligently to expand and improve her business. She hopes to one day own her own workplace. She says, "My goal for the future is to provide quality products and grow my customer base." Tungalag is requesting a 1,350,000-tugrug loan to purchase clothes from China to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: El Carnen Group

texts.es:
El grupo El Carmen está integrado por Jerónima Alejandrina R., Rosibel Angélica T. M. y Álvaro de Jesús C. tres personas trabajadoras, responsables y con mucha esperanza.

Jerónima Alejandrina R. de 38 años empezó vendiendo tortillas cuando ahorro lo suficiente puso un puesto en el mercado donde vende calculadoras desde hace 6 años. 

Su compañera de grupo Rosibel Angélica T. M. produce y vende frutas y verduras en el mercado. Mientras Álvaro de Jesús C. es agricultor desde que nació y comercializa lo que produce.
texts.en:
The El Carmen Group consists of Jerónima Alejandrina R., Rosibel Angélica T. M. and Álvaro de Jesús C., three hard-working and responsible people with high hopes. Jerónima is 38 years old and started out selling tortillas and saved enough to have her own post in the market where she has sold calculators for the past six years. Her partner in the group, Rosibel, grows fruits and vegetables and sells them at the markets. Meanwhile, Álvaro has been a farmer since he was born and sells what he grows.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase calculators and other supplies

loans.name: Bettielyne

texts.en:
Bettielyne R. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Bettielyne is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Bettielyne owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food & daily use products in the local community. Bettielyne has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Bettielyne joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bettielyne has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Bettielyne is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Bettielyne from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Shaloon Group

texts.es:
El grupo Shaloon está integrado por María Antonia F. S.,  Sonia Teresa M., Cándida Rosa J. P., Judith Raquel S. S. y Maura del Carmen Velásquez ellas son mujeres trabajadoras que desde muy jóvenes han tenido que laborar arduamente.

María Antonia F. S. de 54 años empezó hace 30 años vendiendo ajeno ahora ella misma produce las cajetas con ayuda de sus hijas.Mientras Judith Raquel S. S. de 28 años se dedica hacer y vender cajeta desde niña cuyo negocio ha ido de generacion en generación

En cambio Sonia Teresa M. vende productos de la Avon, ropa interior y hace ropa y manteles tejidos, Cándida Rosa J. P. hace pan y nacatamales los fines de semana y Maura del Carmen Velásquez vende comida en el mercado de Masaya.
texts.en:
The Shaloon Group consists of María Antonia F. S., Sonia Teresa M., Cándida Rosa J. P., Judith Raquel S. S. and Maura del Carmen Velásquez, who have all been hard-working women since they were very young. María Antonia is 54 years old and started selling sweets 30 years ago. She makes her products herself with the help of her daughters. Meanwhile, Judith Raquel is 28 years old and also makes and sells sweets, which she has done since she was a little girl. It is a business that has been handed down from generation to generation in her family. Sonia Teresa, on the other hand, sells Avon products and undergarments and also makes clothing and woven tablecloths. Cándida Rosa makes bread and tamales on the weekend, and Maura del Carmen sells food in the Masaya market.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Sharifullah

texts.en:
Sharifullah the son of Sultan M. is 35 years old, married and the father of 5 children, three sons and two daughters. He is a professional and experienced mechanic who runs a workshop with three workers. Currently, his business income is not enough to meet his family's needs and to provide a salary to his workers. Therefore he has requested to take an individual loan of 40000 Afghani for the purpose of purchasing modern and good quality equipments for his workshop. This will held Sharifullah repair cars more easily and increase his business income to meet both the needs of his own family and those of his workers' too.

He would like to thank both AFS and Kiva lenders that support the people around the world through their effective process.

loans.use: to purchase modern motor workshop equipment

The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as powder soap for laundry, coffee (in sachets), shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Michille has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Michille joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda C., 46, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Hilario C., a lead man in construction, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling dried fish and frozen meat for nine years.

Gilda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than eight years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow 15 times in CCT’s cooperative. She has been consistent in paying her dues because she used almost all the borrowed money to buy assorted dried fish and meat and resold it in the market. Her business lets her earn a net profit of 19,000 PHP per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a loan of  25,000 PHP. This amount will be mostly used as added capital for her expanding business through buying dried squid, assorted dried fish, chicken, hot dogs and other frozen meat.

She dreams that through her business she and her husband can let their children finish their studies so that they can have a good life in the future. 


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy dried squid, assorted dried fish, chicken, hot dogs and other frozen meat.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
N. K. Betty is a 48-year-old businesswoman and the mother of four children. She has a poultry farm in her area. She started the business six years ago. 

She is using the loan to purchase more chickens, feed for her poultry, medications, etc. She wants to extend her poultry structure so that she can manage to rear different breeds, that is to say, layers and broilers. Her aim is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens, feed for her poultry, medications, etc.

texts.en:
Mercedes E., 55, is a hardworking businesswoman. She is married to Juanito E., a direct seller of different products. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been direct selling assorted cosmetic products and branded clothes for eight years.

Mercedes has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than four years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow 10 times in CCT’s cooperative. Her business lets her earn an average profit of 15,000 PHP per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a loan of 12,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy assorted cosmetics, branded clothes and shoes.

She dreams that her business will grow into a franchise store so that she can gain big profits and experience a good status in life. 


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy assorted cosmetics, branded clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose F. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Rose is 30 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.


BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Ahmad Jan

texts.en:
Ahmad Jan is a hardworking man. He is uneducated, but he has a great deal of experience in retail. He has been involved in this business for six years in Jalalabad city. He is married and has two children, and is responsible for all of his family.

Through the years he tried many times to enlarge his store, but he couldn't until he found AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint Stock Company) in Jalalabad, Afghanistan. He was really very happy and then decided to apply for a loan. He requested an individual loan of 50,000 AFN to expand his business capacity and increase his business income. He is grateful for all Kiva lenders around the world.

loans.use: to expand his business capacity

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: M. Emmanuel is a 49-year-old businessman. He is the father of three kids. He has a retail shop in his area. He started the business five years ago. He is using the loan to purchase food items and other products, such as soap, wheat flour, basins, cooking oil, and so forth, for the expansion of his business. His aim is to buy a plot of land and to educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell to expand his business.

loans.name: Hikmat

texts.en: Hikmat is 35 years old, married, and has two children. The family lives in Baku city. He has been in this business for three years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy the necessary things for improving his carpenter business.

loans.use: to buy the necessary things for improving his carpenter business

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
keji R. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell. keji is 40 years old and is married to a businessman. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Jemty

texts.en:
Jemty T. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, beans and onions in the market, and is requesting a loan to purchase jerry cans of cooking oil to sell. Jemty is 30 years old. Her husband is a driver. She has one child, and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to purchase jerry cans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia F. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Lucia is 39 years old and is married to a policeman. She has eight children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a big shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Kisakye Development Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
M. Margaret is the leader of her lending group. She is 46 years old and married with seven children aged 24, 22, 20, 18, 15, 14, & 12. Margaret has been a farmer for seven years as well as handling rental properties for two years in Kasenge. She is able to make about $210 in profits per month.

She says that she has been successful because of her fair prices and having quality products for her customers. She has both crops and animals on her farm, and her dream is to have more animals for farm expansion. She would also like to educate her children to the highest level.

Margaret needs a loan to be able to diversify her farming activities and rear more animals by buying more seedlings and cows, goats and pigs for expansion. She is a very determined lady.

(The credit officer had divided the group into two sub-groups, yet their loan is below the Kiva limit and he conducted only one interview, hence the sub-groups are merged.)

loans.use: to buy more seedlings and animals for business expansion.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa B., 48, is doing all that she can so that all of her family's daily needs are provided for. Married to Elmer B., a car mechanic, they are blessed with eight children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been busy managing her own variety store for five years.

Teresa has been a regular member of the Kiva field partner, Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow five times through the CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to add stock to her store. Her business lets her earn a profit of about $200 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for an 8,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying prime commodity products.

She dreams that her store could eventually become a mini-grocery and prays for a peaceful and blessed family life. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy prime commodity products like shampoos, laundry detergents, etc.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and sugar at home and is requesting a loan to open up a retail shop.  Stella is 48 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for herself.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to open up a retail shop.

loans.name: Guandulin

texts.en: Guandulin M. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Guandulin owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks like grilled banana with butter and other delicacies in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Guandulin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jonah

texts.en:
Jonah C. M., 38, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Luis M. and they are blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been making slippers and bags and selling them to her customers for three years.

Jonah has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow three times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used almost all the money she borrowed to buy raw materials for her sandals and slipper making.  Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 7,000 per month.

Now with your help, Jonah would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying leather, sewing materials and other fabrics for her footwear business.

Jonah dreams that her products will become well-known someday and prays that they will have enough money so that they can help those who are in need.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy materials for her footwear and bag-making business

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en: Kiden R. is currently in the business of selling food in her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer and sodas to sell. Kiden is 27 years old and is married to an accountant. She has two children, both of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Kiden hopes to be able to open a hotel (meaning a larger restaurant). About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Rugaaga I Twimukye Of Ibanda Group

texts.en:
K. Mackleen is 49 years old and married with six children, all in secondary school. She also takes care of one dependent.

Mackleen is a farmer, selling produce from Rugaaga I, and from her transactions she is able to make 260,000/= (Ugandan Shillings) as profits every week. She has been a farmer selling produce for fourteen years and is grateful that she has been able to win more customers due to her quality produce.

Mackleen needs a loan to help with buying more produce for resale plus employing manpower on her farm for better output.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell and to employ manpower on her farm

loans.name: Twaha

texts.en:
M. Twaha is a businessman, 46 years old, and the father of five kids. He has a metal workshop in Abaita Ababiri Trading Centre. He started his business five years back.

Twaha is using the loan to purchase metal materials for making metal doors, windows, tanks, and so on, to expand his business. His aim is to expand his house and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase metal materials for his business

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
N. Scovia is a businesswoman, 30 years old, and is the mother of three kids. She has a poultry business four kilometers from Abaita Ababiri. She started her business three years back.

Scovia is using the loan to purchase feeds, drugs and more chicks for her poultry farm. Her target is to have healthy poultry to attract customers.

Scovia’s future plans are to obtain a plot of land in her own name, to construct some rental houses for income generation and to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase feeds, drugs and more chicks for her poultry farm

loans.name: Kakunama 2 Twetungure Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
T. Rose is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is a friendly, determined and hardworking lady and is married with six children who are in secondary and primary schools. She also cares for two dependents.

Rose has had a retail shop as her business for eight years and, although she tries so hard to make it stand, she faces a challenge of bad debtors that take goods and fail or take very long to pay back. However, she is able to make 140,000/= in profits per month due to the good products and good customer care that keep on attracting more and more customers. Rose has a dream of expanding her business further so that she can have a very happy family in future.

Rose also has plantations and animals like cows and goats that she keeps and she is able to make monthly profits from the sale of produce that usually helps with expanding her businesses, taking care of her family, and paying her children’s school fees.

Rose needs another loan to be able to restock her retail shop with more goods like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil and bread, plus buy more cows for her kraal’s (a fenced enclosure) expansion.

loans.use: To restock her shop and to buy more cows for her kraal

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 32 years old and the mother of three children, all of whom are in primary school. Her eldest child is 11 years old. Grace and her family live in Benin City, Edo State. Her husband is a civil servant.

Grace sells groceries at retail prices to her customers and has been in this business for three years. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

Grace is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Queen

texts.en:
Queen is 35 years old and is married with five children. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Queen sells VCDs and is happy that her business is doing well. She is also a hairstylist and she sells groceries. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family. She hopes for a better education for her children.

Queen is requesting a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Queen is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
N. Angela is a businesswoman, 39 years old, and the mother of two kids. She has a fabric shop in Abaita Ababiri Trading Centre. She started her business nine years ago.

Angela is using her loan to purchase garments or clothing material for Gomesi (a long, formal, colorful full-length dress for women) and bisilo (belts to tie a Gomesi) so as to expand her business.

Angela wants to construct some rental houses and she wishes to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase garments or clothing material to expand her business

loans.name: Rasheed

texts.en:
Rasheed is 33 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Rasheed is a client of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organization. She sells groceries and foodstuffs to make a living, and this business is a major source of income to her. She hopes to make her business sustainable and be able to meet the basic needs of her family. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

About Lift Above Poverty Organization
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Katojo Abamwe Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
M. Teddy is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is a hardworking businesswoman who has been selling matooke (a green plantain dish) from Katojo Cell for seven years. Teddy is married with seven children, all of whom are at university or secondary school. Her business profits of 170,000 UGX a month enable her to pay their school fees.
Teddy ensures that she has good produce for sale, and this allows her to maximize her products depending on her stock and capital. She would like to make more profit as well as have a happy and healthy family. Teddy is requesting a loan to improve her banana plantation by buying manure and fertilizers for better output. She is grateful for her previous loans because they have helped her business and her family's welfare very much.

loans.use: To buy manure and fertilizers for her banana plantation

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: N. Justine is a 48-year-old businesswoman and mother of two children. She has a clothes shop in Abaita Ababiri trading centre, which she started three years ago. Justine is using her loan to purchase stock for her shop in order to meet customer demand. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and educate her children to university level.

loans.use: To purchase stock for her clothes shop

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: K. Henry is a 33-year-old businessman and a married father of four children. Henry has a fish business, and is using his loan to purchase fish from fishermen to resell in Abaita Ababiri market. He hopes to expand his business in order to generate better profits. His dream is to educate his children and purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase fish from fishermen to resell

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: N. Rachael is a 38-year-old businesswoman and mother of four children. For the past two years she has run a clothes shop in Abaita Ababiri trading centre. Rachael is using her loan to purchase more stock to sell in her shop. Her intentions are to work very hard to obtain a plot of land on which to build rental houses for monthly income.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her clothes shop

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 57 years old and married with seven children. Some of her children are at university while others are in secondary school. Lucy is a client of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO). She has a restaurant where she sells drinks and cooked foods to make a living. She has been in this business for a long time. Lucy is requesting a loan of 20,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

About Lift Above Poverty Organization
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Ami

texts.fr:
Madame ami K. est une femme de 54 ans qui habite dans le quartier de Layenne a Yoff. Elle est divorce et mère de 2 enfants dont l’âgé varie entre 14 et 16 ans. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC de Yoff depuis octobre 2009. Les occupations de Madame K. sont surtout orientées vers la couture et le commerce. Elle s’est très tôt lancée dans la couture depuis 1973 aussitôt qu’elle a abandonne les études. Ainsi sa maman l’a beaucoup motive dans l’activité de couturière. Ce qui lui plait le plus ce sont les progrès effectues et aussi la confection de beaux habits qu’elle fait. Disposant d’une seule machine a coudre  Madame K. souhaiterait une seconde pour une meilleure compétitivité de son travail.
Madame K. a une activité secondaire qui est la vente de beignet a cote de son domicile. Elle emprunte 250 000 frs pour l’acquisition d’une deuxième machine. Le reste de l’argent va lui permettre d’acheter des sacs de mil et de sucre destines a la préparation des beignets a base de mil  qu’elle commercialise. L’évolution de son activité et par conséquent l’accroissement de ses profits lui permettent de gérer la dépense quotidienne et de constituer un soutien a ma petite famille.                  
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs Ami K. is a 54-year old woman who lives in the Layenne neighborhood of Yoff. She is divorced and has two children who are 14 and 16 years old. She has been a member of the Yoff savings bank which belongs to U-IMCEC (a mutual loan and savings union) since October 2009. Mrs K.'s specialises primarily in sewing and trading. She ventured into sewing as early as 1973 when she abandoned her studies. Her mother strongly encouraged her in her sewing activity. What pleases her most is the progress she has achieved and also the fabrication of beautiful costumes. Mrs K. has a secondary activity which is the sale of fritters next to her home. She is borrowing 250,000 francs for the acquisition of a second machine. The rest of the money will allow her to buy bags of millet and sugar in order to make the millet-based fritters that she sells. The development of her business and the consequent growth in her profits will allow her to cover her daily expenses and provide financial support for her small family. As part of the ongoing vision to participate actively in the battle against poverty, U-IMCEC, with the backing of its lenders, is successfully supporting people to carry out lucrative revenue-generating activities; this in turn is contributing to a welcome socio-economic development.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of working capital and investment

loans.name: Apollo

texts.en: T. Apollo is a 28-year-old businessman and father of three children. For the past five years, he has run a retail shop where he sells essentials. Apollo is using his loan to purchase retail items such as drinks, bread, sweets, soap, salt, sugar, etc. for sale. His future hopes are to expand his business, educate his children, and obtain a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as drinks, bread, sweets, soap, salt, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Osayuki

texts.en:
Osayuki is 34 years old and married with four children, the youngest of whom is one year old. She is a client of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organization. Osayuki sells groceries and foodstuffs to earn a living. She has been in this business for a long time. In the future, Osayuki hopes to own a supermarket. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

About Lift Above Poverty Organization
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kahengye Group, Rukungiri

texts.en: A. Innocent is the leader of her lending group in Rukungiri. She is a married lady with four children, two in secondary school and two in primary school. She also takes care of 2 dependents. Innocent has had a grocery business in Kahengye Trading centre for 10 years. Her customers are local people and she says that she is faced with a low market for her goods. Innocent says that she is able to make 80,000 UGX/ a week as profits. Her goal is to enlarge her business so that she is able to serve Rukungiri town. This would allow her to continue saving more towards educating her children to the University level. She needs a loan to buy more vegetables and fresh fruits for her business and this will help her pay her children’s school fees with much ease. Innocent is such a determined lady.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and fresh fruits for resale.

loans.name: Ramatoulaye

texts.fr:
Madame Ramatoulaye S. est une dame de 36 ans mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 1 an 3mois et 13 ans. Elle habite dans le quartier de Tonghor à Yoff. Elle est membre de la caisse de Yoff depuis décembre 2006 et n’a jamais bénéficié de prêt antérieur.
Son activité primaire concerne la vente de boubous et chaussures. Elle capitalise une expérience de 4 ans. C’est sur une table devant chez elle qu’elle expose ses marchandises. Elle est aussi très bien connue dans les tresses dans le quartier. Elle a choisi cette activité de commerce grâce a l’encouragement de sa maman. L’avantage pour elle c’est la rentabilité et le statut de non dépendance qui en découle. Madame S. a l’intention de diversifier un peu son activité  et démarrer le petit commerce de bonbons divers pour les enfants. A cet effet elle sollicite un crédit de 75 000 frs.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs Ramatoulaye S., aged 36, is married and the mother of four children. The youngest is 1 year and 3 months old and the oldest is 13. She lives in the neighborhood of Tonghor in Yoff. She has been a member of the Yoff branch of the microfinance institution U-IMCEC since December 2006, but never took out a loan.

Her primary activity is the sale of boubous (a type of clothing worn by men and women in West Africa) and shoes. She built up a 4-year-long experience. She displays her merchandise on a table in front of her house. She is also well known in the neighborhood for her braids. She was encouraged by her mother to choose this trade activity. She enjoys the profitability and independence. Currently Mrs S. wants to diversify her activity and sell candies to children. This is why she applies for a loan of 75,000 CFA francs.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC – with the positive support of lenders – succeeds in supporting people in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero is married with 6 children. Her youngest child is 8 years old. She is 43 years old. She is a LAPO client. (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else where in Africa. Vero sells used clothes to earn a living. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. Vero hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more used clothes to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is married with 4 children. Her youngest child is 13 years old. She is 39 years old. She is a LAPO client. (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Florence sells groceries and food items to earn a living. She has been in this business for a long time.  She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. Florence hopes for a loan amount of NGN 170,000 to purchase more groceries and food items to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and food items to sell.

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty is married and has 4 children. Her youngest child is 7 years old. She is 47 years old. She is a LAPO client. (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else where in Africa. Beauty sells groceries and food items to earn a living. She has been in this business for a long time.  She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. Beauty hopes for a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more groceries and food to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and food to sell.

loans.name: Eunice Nyamweru

texts.en:
Eunice is married to John and they have three children: Kennedy, Peter and Patrick.

Eunice was introduced to KADET through existing clients. She is servicing her second loan and has no previous serviced loan from other Micro Finance Institutions. She intends to use the loan to increase stock in her hardware shop: inventory such as plumbing materials, paint and tiles.

Eunice's area of business is situated along a highway where there are many houses being developed. This ensures her a steady demand for her goods, which are used for building the houses. With the extra profits she plans to expand her business.

Eunice hopes to own a chain of hardware stores in Nairobi and other towns as she describes herself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: The loan will be used to increase inventory in her hardware shop.

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi M. is a single mother of four children. She lives in Mariakani town in the coast province of Kenya. Sidi operates her business in Mariakani market and she mainly sells dried fish to the area residents. She has been selling this type of fish for 11 years and has been able to satisfy a big number of the area residents.

Sidi has been a KADET member for a long time and she is now accessing her third loan. With this loan she plans to purchase 15 sacks of dried fish and to expand her business to another new town called Mwanda.

Through her business, Sidi has been able to educate her children well. She hopes to expand the business now to a nearby town and grow more.

loans.use: To purchase 15 sacks of dried fish and to expand her business to another new town.

loans.name: Zaki

texts.en: Zaki is an electrician. He has been working in this sector since 1997. He’s 29 years old and married with one child. He works hard to satisfy his family's needs. Today, Zaki is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy a special compressor, designed for his work, in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy a special compressor designed for his work.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: S. Alice is a business person. She is thirty-seven years old, the mother of one child. She is operating in a rental shop, selling retail items such as sugar, salt, drinks, soap, bread, etc. She has been operating her business for over five years now. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, bread, etc. to sell. Her future hope is to purchase a plot of land and to finance the education of her child.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, drinks, soap, bread, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 27-year-old married man with one young child. He has owned a signboard shop in his town since 2004. Over time, he has become well known in his village and its surroundings. Today Ahmad requests a loan of $1,200 to buy more inventory and tools to continue to cater to his clients.

loans.use: buy more inventory and tools

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: K. Sarah is a businesswoman of thirty-four years old.  She is a married woman blessed with three children. She has run a spare parts shop for the past five years. She will use the loan to purchase spare parts to satisfy her customers’ needs. She really hopes to improve upon her business. Her aim is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to satisfy her customers’ needs

loans.name: Fariz

texts.en: B. Fariz is single. He was born 1986 and lives in the Fuzuli region. He has been in the livestock business for 2 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy 8 sheep to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy 8 sheep

loans.name: Bachir

texts.en: Bachir has worked as a blacksmith since 2004 to help his father with the family income. He is 24 years old. He is planning to expand and develop his business. In order to do so, he's requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy more tools for his business.

loans.use: to buy more tools

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en: Augustine is married with 5 children. He is an LAPO client. Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Augustine sells building materials to earn a living. He has been in this business for a long time.  He hopes to expand his business in the future. Augustine hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. He thanks all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 24-year-old single man. In 2006, he decided to work as a home electrician. On a freelance basis, he works on house projects in his town and its surroundings. With the help the requested $1,200 loan, he can expand his business by buying tools to be able to take on more projects.

loans.use: to buy tools

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy  B. is a 32-year-old businesswoman. She is a married and has two children. She operates a retail shop business that she opened twelve years ago. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as salt, jerry cans, bread, sugar, soap, paraffin, curry powder, match boxes, and so forth.  She is an engaging businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items to sell

loans.name: Ihingiro Development Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
Denis B. is the leader of his lending group in Rukungiri. He is 40 years old and married, and has four children, ages 8 - 13 years old. They also care for an orphan. All of the children are in primary school. 

Denis has a bar and a butcher shop, where he sells pork, in Katojo Cell Buyanja Trading Centre. He has run his business for 15 years and he is able to make 70,000/= (Ugandan shillings) in profit every week. He attributes his success to having confidence in himself and his business, in addition to the trust from his customers.

He would like to buy a car to help with the transportation for his business and to hire out as a taxi. He also hopes to educate his children to higher standards. Denis would like to restock his businesses by buying more beer, soda, a pig, and other meat to open new markets in other areas in the future. He is such a hard-working man.

loans.use: To buy meat and pork to sell in his butcher shop, and to buy more beer for his bar.

loans.name: Hala

texts.en:
Hala is a 29-year-old married woman and the mother of two children, She has been working as a home-based tailor since 2006 to help her husband to support their household. 

Hala is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy more textiles and tailoring tools to produce a greater variety of products for her clients.

loans.use: To buy more textiles and tailoring tools

loans.name: Sabukhi

texts.en: Sabukhi D. is married and has one child. He lives in the Fuzuli region with his family. He is 31 years old. He has been in the cattle business for three years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy four calves to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy 4 calves

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline N. is a 36-year-old businesswoman. She is married and has six children who are all in school. She has owned a beauty salon since 2004. 

Pauline is using her loan to purchase cosmetics, such as hair chemicals, hair relaxers, hair extensions, and jellies. Her shop is located in the Abaita Ababiri trading centre. Her future plan is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Maher

texts.en: Maher is a 25-year-old married man who has one child. He has been working as an electrician since 2002. He really likes his work and he works hard to improve his family's living conditons. Maher wants to borrow $1,200 to buy an electric motor for his business.

loans.use: To buy an electric motor

loans.name: Kibwagala Group

texts.en:
Chiro R. is 43 years old. She is married, has 5 children, and lives in Dar es Salaam. 

Chiro owns a pharmacy. She also sells eggs from a genge, a basic structure made of wood and tin that is location by roadside. Chiro has been in the business for 6 years and currently earns 160000 shillings a month (~$120 USD).

This will be Chiro’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. With the loan, she hopes to increase the inventory of her pharmacy and renovate her genge to improve her egg selling business. 

Chiro will share this loan with her loan group, which is composed of 14 other women from her community. These women work in food sales and second-hand clothing sales. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.
 
In the picture, Chiro is in the middle of the front row with the bright green head scarf.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of her pharmacy and renovate her egg shop

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en: Hadijah N. is a hardworking businesswoman. She is thirty years old and married, and the mother of two children who are in school. She started a salon business ten years ago. She is using the loan to purchase salon items, such as hair chemicals, relaxes, combs, and hair driers. She is a promising businesswoman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase salon items

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en: Khodor is a 48-year-old married man with 7 children, 4 of whom are still unemployed. He owns a van that he uses to transport students to their schools. He started his business in 2000 with 15 years of previous experience. Today, Khodor is requesting a loan of $1,200 to perform maintenance for on van and replace his vehicle's wheels.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his van and change his vehicle's wheels

loans.name: Preston

texts.en: Preston K. is a 29-year-old businessman. He owns a grocery store in the Zanna area. He started a business four year ago. He is using the loan to purchase items such as tomato sauce, dry cell batteries, sugar, salt, soda, beer, water, rice, and cooking oil to expand his shop. He is a hardworking business man whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Bwanda Bakyara Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
Lydia  B. is 54 years old. She is married and has 9 children. Some of her children are at university, some are in secondary and primary schools, and some have completed school and are now working. 

Lydia sells produce from Rusheshe. She started a very small business 10 years ago, but her business has now grown and she is able to make 60,000/= (Ugandan shillings) in profit each week. She says that she is successful because the loans from Pearl Microfinance have helped her to increase her capital base. She would like to have a large inventory and she hopes to educate her children to the highest levels. 

Lydia needs a loan to purchase more produce  This gives her more stock to satisfy her customer’s needs, and therefore, more sales. She is such a hard-working lady.

loans.use: To buy more produce to resell

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Abass is a 30-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife. Abass has been selling home products for the past three years. He sells shampoos, perfumes, deodorant, tissues, washing products, and lots more. His shop is very well located on a main street in a popular neighborhood. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. 

Abass requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise for his shop and to expand his stock. This is the first time that Abass has requested a loan.

When Abass first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to expand his stock and diversify his merchandise. He decided to start his business because he wanted to work independently and he liked retail sales. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Taleb

texts.en: Taleb is a 27-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He has been working as a farmer since 2000. He cooperates with his five brothers to make a good income for the family. Taleb is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy merchandise, such as fertilizer, tools, and supplies that he needs for his farm.

loans.use: To buy items for his farm, such as fertilizer, tools and supplies

loans.name: Kireku Group, Mukono

texts.en:
Joselyne K. is a hard-working and devoted married woman. She is a businesswoman with a retail shop in Kireku that she has owned for eight years. From her sales, Joselyne is able to make 80,000/= (Ugandan shillings) in profit each week and these help to restock her shop with more goods and to pay her children's school fees. She has six children who are all in school. 

Joselyne dreams of expanding her shop further to have more stock so she can make more reasonable profits. This is her second loan and she is grateful for the positive contribution that the first loan made to her shop.

loans.use: Restock her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: La Paciencia 3 Group

texts.en:
Linda, age 24, lives near the city of Santiago in the Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator of her loan group, "La Paciencia" (Patience), and her story is representative of those of the other borrowers in the group. 

Linda lives at home with her husband and four small children. They have a very basic and small home, just one of the many challenges facing those in the Dominican Republic. Potable running water is nonexistent, electricity is scarce, and health care is inadequate at best. Despite these and other challenges, Linda runs a small business selling used clothing to her friends, neighbors, and community. She plans to use this loan, her first with Esperanza International, to purchase packs of clothing which she will sort through and sell for a small profit.

Unlike many clothing shops, Linda will use a cart to transport her items around town. She hopes that this mobility will give her an edge and add to her sales. With the profits from her business, she hopes to buy items for her children, including backpacks, notebooks, new shoes, and school uniforms. Linda is very grateful for her new access to loans, stating that she is now “much more at ease and [feels] valued as a human being”. Thank you for your loan to Linda and La Paciencia Group!

loans.use: Clothing for men, women, and children

loans.name: Rosita Group

texts.es:
El grupo Rosita está integrado por Rosa Paublina R. M. de 43 años quien vende en su hogar enchiladas, frescos, gaseosas y helados, Bernarda Lourdes T. vende gaseosas, helados y hielo, Aracely del Socorro C.  comercializa ropa y zapatos y por ultimo la menor del grupo Fátima Aracely F. R. de 19 años vende cosméticos y hace rifas.

 Estas cuatro féminas trabajadoras y emprendedoras han buscado la forma de ganarse el pan de cada día de forma honrada con la creación de pequeños comercios que están en pleno crecimiento y que de necesitan inversión para ir  mejorando.
texts.en:
The Rosita group has four members. Rosa Paublina R. M., 43 years old, sells enchiladas, juices, soft drinks, and ice cream from her home. Bernarda Lourdes T. sells soft drinks, ice cream, and ice. Aracely del Socorro C. sells clothing and shoes. And the youngest of the group, Fátima Aracely F. R., 19, sells cosmetics and conducts raffles. These four hardworking and enterprising women have searched for a way to earn their daily bread in an honest way with the creation of these small, growing businesses. They need an investment of capital to continue growing.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks, fruit, grains, etc.

loans.name: Betty

texts.es: Betty tiene 20  años, y cuya familia esta integrada por su hijo de 2 años y sus padres, y del cual vive en casa de ellos. Hace un año que se dedica a la venta de animales menores, siendo este trabajo que le recomendó sus padres, desde entonces tiene su granja y del que se dedica ahora atendiendo a sus cuyes, dando su alimentación, procura cada cierto tiempo asear su galpón permitiendo la salubridad a sus animales y así como por su misma salud. Dentro de esta actividad también se dedica a la crianza de aves de corral, y credos. Es así como Betty cada temporada lleva sus animales a la feria ganadera para venderlos, comercio que le ha dado buenos dividendos cada dos semanas.  De esta manera el ritmo de negocio le ha ayudado obtener más animales para su comercialización. Por lo que espera más adelante contar con una extensa con una buena infraestructura. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, por lo que esta muy contenta por el apoyo que le han brindado, además ha demostrado ser puntual en sus pagos y se siente muy contenta de pertenecer a su grupo comunal. Con el préstamo que solicita lo utilizará en la compra de más animales como cuyes, gallinas y cerdos.
texts.en:
Betty is 20 years old and lives with her son of two years and her parents in their house. At her parent’s encouragement, Betty started selling baby animals a year ago. She has since acquired a small holding where she looks after and feeds her guinea pigs, and, every now and then, tidies her storehouse, making sure everything is kept in a sanitary condition for both her and her animals’ wellbeing. Betty also raises common domesticated fowl and guinea fowl. Every season, Betty takes her animals to the cattle market to sell them, giving her a good income every two weeks. Working at a steady pace allows Betty to buy more animals. In the future, she plans to build on her business and develop a more solid infrastructure. This is Betty’s third loan with MFP, and she is very grateful for the help it provides. Betty is punctual with her repayments and is very pleased to belong to such a cooperative. Betty will use the loan to buy more animals such as guinea pigs, chickens and pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Justine Raymond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more guinea pigs, chickens and pigs.

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Abass is a 25-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Abass has owned and operated a mobile phone shop since 2006. He sells new and used mobile phones and phone accessories, and he also repairs mobile phones. His shop is very well located on a main street in a popular neighborhood, and has lots of experience in his domain. His clients are his friends and neighbors. 

Abass has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase new mobile phones. This is the first time that Abass has requested a loan. When Abass first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided to start his business because he wanted to have an independent work life. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase new mobile phones.

loans.name: Hojalatería Group

texts.es:
El grupo Hojalateria está integrados por tres mujeres que trabajan haciendo sartenes ellas son Ruth F. L., María del Carmen F. y Marcia Marbelly G.. Ellas llevan doce siclos de trabajar con adim es decir unos tres años en los cuales su negocio ha ido mejorando notablemente.

La señora Ruth L. empezó con la producción y ventas de sartenes pero para diversificar las fuentes de ingresó en otros rubros como la venta de ropa en el cual le a ido muy bien.  Su compañera María del Carmen F.  está casada con un agricultor quien para ayudarla vendió una ternera con lo cual ella inicio con su negocio de sartenes y su pequeña venta.

Mientras Marcia Marbelly G. de 22 años inicio a la edad de 12 años a producir sartenes y a vender chiverías, ya que desde muy joven trabajo con su madre en este oficio actualmente ella es independiente.
texts.en:
The Hojalatería Group ("plumber") is composed of three women who produce frying pans: Ruth F. L., María del Carmen F. and Marcia Marbelly G.. Over the past three years they took out twelve loans from the microfinance institution ADIM, which resulted in a marked improvement of their business.

Ruth L. began producing and selling frying pans, but she wanted to diversify her sources of income and added the sale of clothes to her activities, which proved to be a very good decision.
