Lowelyn D., age 46, is from the village of Salvador Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Lowelyn is married and has a child in school. To make a living, Lowelyn operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as bread, candies, shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Lowelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lowelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. Her purpose was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Lowelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC.

Lowelyn is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Lowelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Porferia

texts.en:
Porferia A. is from the village of Becor, Cagay-anon, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old. Porferia is widowed and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Porferia raises pigs for sale. Porferia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Porferia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Porferia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Porferia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Porferia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pigs

loans.name: Ching

texts.en:
P., age 30, is a married woman and is blessed with a young school-aged child. She resides with her husband and child in a medium-sized stone house. She is a good housewife who cooks delicious meals and takes care of her child. P. depends on the income provided by her husband, who is a generator repairer in the cement production industry.

P. has a sister who is determined to obtain a university degree, and she has to pay tuition but doesn't have enough money. For this reason, P. has applied for a $500 loan, which will enable her to help her sister pay for her education.

loans.use: To help her sister pay college tuition fees

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sorn N. lives in Srae Vong village in Takeo province. She is a grocer in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Sarar Sann (shown at left), owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, he is a chicken seller, an activity by which he can earn a little extra money to help provide for his family. They have three children, two of whom are employed in garment factories; the third is a student.

Mrs. Sorn N. wants to expand her business. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy grocery goods to sell, and she would like to use the rest of the money to buy a motorbike for her husband so that he can sell chickens door to door.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for sale and to buy a motorbike for her husband to sell chickens door to door

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mr. Sarin H. lives in Neal village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, he faces some problems because he does not have enough money to buy rice seeds and ducks. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy these for his purpose.

His wife, Mrs. Sokha Chann, is duck breeder. Mr. Sarin H. is the father has two children one of whom works in a casino club while the young one is a student.

loans.use: To buy rice seed for his land and ducks for his wife's business

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Pech S., 31 years old, has been married for a long time to Mr. Bunthoeun, who is with her in the photo and is a generator repairman in the garment factory. This couple has a young child who attends school and is dependent on them.

To earn a living, Pech S. always leaves home to work sewing clothes in the garment industry and normally makes a salary of $100 each month which she uses to serve her family’s daily food needs.

Pech S. faces difficulty traveling to her work location and she usually takes a taxi or walks to work. Because of that, she is applying for a loan in order to purchase a used motorcycle which will enable her to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle to ride to work

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet R. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Juliet owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling coconuts in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Chroeb C. is the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. She lives in Srae Vong Village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Vuth Soun, is shown on the left of the photo. He is farmer who is able to make a small income for his family.

Mrs. Chroeb C. is a grocer. She would like to improve and increase her income to support her family so she decided to ask for a loan from AMK to start a new business selling tamarinds (the pods of a tree, widely used as a flavoring in Asian cooking). She would like to use the rest of the loan to buy a motorbike to transport tamarinds to re-sell.

loans.use: To start a business selling tamarinds and to buy a motorbike to transport them

loans.name: Arturo

texts.en: Arturo A. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 30 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Arturo owns and operates a business providing motorcycle services to transport passengers in the local community. He is just starting this business. In 2009, Arturo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to repair a motorcycle used in his business. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a motorcycle used in his business

loans.name: Eib

texts.en: Mrs. Eib M. lives in Prey Bay village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a half hectare field on which she grows rice. In this plantation, she faces some problems because her field is infertile soil and it is far from any irrigation system. She decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine, fertilizer, rice seed, and pesticide to improve the crop growth. Her husband, Mr. Touch Deng, owns a plowing machine which he hires out to villagers to plow their fields.  Aside from this work, he helps his wife with the rice farming. Mrs. Eib M. is 50 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are still attending school.

loans.use: To buy a water machine, fertilizer, rice seed, and pesticide to grow rice.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou E. is from the village of Guinsiliban in Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old and married with 4 school-aged children.  Marilou is just starting a clothing retail store and she has joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help start the business. She is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase clothing to sell.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for her store.

loans.name: Chak

texts.en: Chak P., 36 years old, has been a tailor in the garment factory for many years and currently earns $120 a month which she uses to cover her family’s daily living expenses. Chak P. was married but has been divorced from her husband since her three kids were very young. All three of her children study at the primary school and are dependent on her. Chak P. faces possible health problems resulting from polluted water surrounding her house, and she requests a loan to purchase fill dirt to improve the condition of her property.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land.

loans.name: Soeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeb C. is the mother of four children who are all students. She lives in Prey Bay village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Soeb C. is a farmer who owns small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Noeun Morm, is a duck breeder who is able to earn a small income to help his family. He is shown on the right in the photo.

Since her husband’s duck business is going well, he wants to expand it so Mrs. Soeb C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for her husband's business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Phany

texts.en:
Mrs. Phany N. lives in Mea Neak village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.3-hectare (3.25-acre) piece of land on which she cultivates rice.

In this plantation, Mrs. Phany N. faces some problems because she does not have enough money to support her field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer. The rest of the loan she would use to buy pig feed because her husband, Mr. Pov Soat, is a pig breeder who is able to earn a small income to help his family.

Mrs. Phany N. is the mother of two children who are too young to go to school or to work. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer plus pig feed for her husband's business

loans.name: Maricyle

texts.en: Maricyle G.'s main source of income comes from buying and selling coconut (locally known as copras) in her community. She is a 23-year-old single woman from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin province. Maricyle is just starting this business. In 2009, Maricyle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Maricyle is requesting a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chreach

texts.en: Mrs. Chreach K. is 41 years old. She lives in Mea Neak village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field on which she grows rice.  She has a machine for watering her field, but now she does not have enough money to cultivate her field. Thus, Mrs. Chreach K. requests a loan from AMK to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and fuel.  Her husband, Mr. Rorn Vann, is a duck breeder, so the rest of the loan will be used to buy food for the ducks and more ducklings.  Mrs. Chreach K. is the mother of six children, five of whom are students and the other is a worker.  Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and fuel.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes H. is from the village of Guinsiliban in Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old and married with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lourdes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lourdes from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Khin

texts.en: Mr. Khin S. is 38 years old and resides in an area of Reusey Kao Commune in Phnom Penh capital, where he lives with his family and other members. He now has five teenage children. One of his daughters works sewing clothing and the remaining four attend school. His wife, Sophal, 43, is a local farmer. To make a living, Khin S. works as a security guard for a garment company. He will use his first loan to buy a plot of land as well as buy rice to resell at a profit.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land and to buy rice.

loans.name: Jusilene

texts.en: Jusilene A. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling food and daily use products like eggs, canned goods, coffee, milk and more in her community. She is 39 years old, married and has two grown-up children. She is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. Jusilene has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Jusilene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jusilene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase products to sell. Jusilene is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Srey Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Touch N. is 27 years old. She lives in Bam village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Ladang Sorm, are pig middlemen who wish to make a little more money to support their family, but she does not have enough money to buy more pigs. Thus, Mrs. Srey Touch N. requests a loan from AMK to buy more pigs to resell.  Mrs. Srey Touch N. is the mother of three children.  Two attend the local school but the youngest one is still too young.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to resell.

loans.name: Sokun

texts.en: Mrs. Sokun K. lives in Chambok village in Takeo province. She is a grocer who earns a small income to help support her family. She now wants to expand her business so she decided to request a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Sey Cheam, is an electrician. Mrs. Sokun K. is a mother of three children who are all students.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for resale.

loans.name: En

texts.en: Mrs. En R. lives in Neasa Kiri village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who has owns a 1-hectare field on which she grows rice. In this plantation, she has some obstacles because her soil is infertile and has lots of insects so she wants a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticide, and to pay for laborers. Her husband, Mr. Phos Cheung, is also farmer. Mrs. En R. is 40 years old. She is a mother of four children, one who works in a garment factoR. while the other three attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticide, and to pay for laborers.

loans.name: Nhoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhoem N. is a farmer who owns a 1.2 hectare field of land to cultivate rice. She is the mother of six children:  three are farmers while the others are students. Her husband, Mr. Bros Men, helps her with the farming (he is on the right in the photo). They live in Neasa Kiri village in Takeo province. 

With her farm, Mrs. Nhoem N. earns a small income to support her family. She is having some problems because her field has infertile soil. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and make it more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mr. Thoeun C. and his wife are both are shown in the photo. This young couple has been married a year and hope to have their first child next year.  In order to earn enough to support a family, Thoeun C. and his wife work at a garment factory, earning over $200 a month, and Thoeun C. also hopes to invest in a new enterprise in order to make his family income more stable. Thoeun C. requests a $700 loan which he will use to buy rice in bulk to resell at a profit.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny S. is 30 years old and lives in Chambok village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare field for growing rice. She faces some problems because her soil is infertile and the field is far from the irrigation system. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine, hoses, fertilizer, rice seed, and pesticides for rice farming. Her husband, Mr. Bo Rat Orn, is also a farmer.  Mrs. Ny S. is the mother of two children who both attend school.

loans.use: To buy a water machine, hoses, fertilizer, rice seed, and pesticides to grow rice.

loans.name: Jofeler

texts.en:
Jofeler A. is from the village of Mahinog in Camiguin province. He is 25 years old and single. To make a living, Jofeler provides motorcycle transport within the local community, and he has been doing so for over 5 years. He earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jofeler joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jofeler has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Jofeler is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Jofeler from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand services provided.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina C.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. She is 41 years old, married and has four grown-up children. She is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. Lina has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Lina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. Lina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen S., 49 years of age, has been earning a living by growing rice and vegetable on her own land, next to her house, in the village. She is married with six children: two grown children are already married and have been living separately, and the others are single, sewing workers in a factory. Pen S. was married years ago to Mr. Siem, age 50, who is a mobile worker building houses. Pen S. and her husband are facing difficulties with transportation to work and other places because they don’t have their own vehicle for traveling purposes. Pen S. is therefore applying for a loan to buy a new motorbike for her family’s transportation needs.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros C., 25, is a young married lady and a hard working woman who resides in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is married with a child who is a minor and not enrolled in school. Her husband, Vanna, 25, is with her in the photo. He works as a staff member for a transportation company. To earn an income to help cover the family's daily needs, Ros C. owns a grocery shop inside the Chom Puvan market where she sells a variety of cooking ingredients. She is able to generate a daily income of $5 a day, which she uses to feed her family, especially her child. Ros C. needs a loan to buy a motorcycle to use as transportation and she intends to use any money remaining from the loan to increase the financial capital of her grocery sale business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle and to increase her financial capital

loans.name: Sanyu Development Group, Mukono

texts.en: A. Grace is a hard working lady with a lot of vision. She is married with four children all in school. She is a tailor in Kirinya and has had a retail shop in the same area for six. She is able to make 30,000/= profit every day. Grace makes ladies traditional wear casual wear, children’s wear and school uniforms even while managing her retail shop. On top of these two businesses, Grace would like to join agriculture / farming since her husband is a civil servant and the money they make so far will not be enough to take their children through secondary and University levels of school. Grace needs a loan to be able to restock her retail shop with more goods to increase her income.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Kiwanga Twegatte Group, Mukono

texts.en: B. Agnes is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a single mother of three children. Two of her children are in school and the other is a baby. She also takes care of one dependant. Agnes has had a salon in Kiwanga for five years doing both women and men’s hairstyles. Ever since she started using loans in her business, Agnes has been able to grow her business. She makes more profit compared to the time before the loans. She needs a loan to be able to restock her salon with more hair oils, weaves, hairpieces and chemicals so that she can treat her customers to their satisfaction.

loans.use: To restock her salon.

loans.name: Ulezi Group

texts.en:
S. S. is 53 years old, married with seven children and lives just outside Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, in a village called Goba. Since 1997, S. has owned and operated a fish selling business. In the morning, he meets fishermen at the ferry terminal to buy fresh fish. He brings the fish back to his community, roasts it, and sells it from a small stall on the side of the road. At his stall, he also sells local food, which is his primary source of income. Earning only 40,000 Tanzanian shillings a month ($30 USD), S.’s family survives on the fish and the foodstuffs he sells.

This will be S.’s first Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. He hopes to obtain this loan to increase his food inventory and improve the appearance of his food stall to attract more customers. 

S. will share this loan with his loan group, which totals 12 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, S. is in the middle wearing a striped shirt.

loans.use: To make improvements to his food stall to attract more business

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam S., age 54, is married with two children who are no longer in school. One of her children is married and the other one sells grocery items out of her home in her village. Sam S. was married, but her husband died of senility. She currently uses her own land next to her house to grow rice and vegetables to earn a living. Sam S. also relies on her daughter’s income as a grocery seller to support their family and recently she is out of some of the grocery items. Sam S. wants a loan to purchase more grocery inventory and the rest of the loan she will use to grow crops.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory and to grow crops.

loans.name: Kireka Market Vendors Group, Mukono

texts.en: N. Safina is 50 years old and the leader of her lending group. She is married with four children and has had a boutique as her business in Kireka for 10 years. She currently makes 50,000/= profit every week. Her main business challenge is having inadequate capital for expansion hence the reason for the little profit she makes. However, she tries so hard to attract more customers due to her good customer care skills and she would like to expand her business further for more profits. Safina needs a loan to be able to restock her boutique with more quality clothes for resale. She is such a friendly and hard working lady.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her boutique.

loans.name: Hope Group 1, Mukono

texts.en: K. Rose is 37 years old and married with four children aged 14 – 5 years. They are all in school and she takes care of other orphans. Rose has had a poultry farm business in Kigombya for two years.  She is able to make 400,000/= profit per month from the sale of eggs and broilers for meat. She says that she is faced with the high price of chicken feed due to the season but otherwise, her business is good. She has hopes of expanding her business plus educating her children to the highest level. Rose needs a loan to be able to buy more day old chicks for her farm expansion and to buy more feed for the existing chickens. She will save money by buying in bulk.

loans.use: To buy day old chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him H. is 54 years of age and a resident of Siem Reap province, where she makes her daily income by selling a few fish at the local market. Him H. was married but divorced her husband when both her children were young. One of her children is married and lives independently, while the other one is a single daughter wH. works as a waitress in a restaurant. Beside her fish sale enterprise, she always took time to farm rice as her annual trade. When the drying rice season comes, Him H. aims to plant rice and raise pigs, from which she will earn extra income. Because of a lack money, Him H. needs a loan from Kiva through HKL.

loans.use: To plant rice and raise pigs.

loans.name: Hope Group 2, Mukono

texts.en: S. Grace is 45 years old and divorced with seven children of her own in her care. She has been in the business of selling clothes from Kikko for nine years, from which she makes about $315 in profit a week, although she still faces the challenge of lacking enough capital. She makes certain that her stock is of good quality, which attracts more customers. Grace has hopes of building a house for her children plus educating them to the University for Self Reliance in the future. She needs a loan to be able to buy more quality clothes for resale.

loans.use: Buy more clothes for her shop expansion.

loans.name: Chheuy

texts.en: Chheuy S. is 45 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. Since 2000, she has been selling fish at the local market to earn a living and is able to make about $8 a day. Her husband is a rice farmer, and on average he is able to make $2 a day. This couple has three children, two of whom are students and one who is a receptionist at a local hotel. Chheuy S. is asking for a loan of $800 so that she can purchase a motorbike for transporting fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Salesio

texts.en:
Salesio is married to Wanjiru and they have three children: Cynthia, David and Mercy.

Salesio was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he is servicing his first loan. He has never borrowed from another Micro-Finance Institution before. Salesio has been in the secondhand shoes supply business for seven years. He intends to use the loan to purchase shoes from other external markets.

Salesio's field of business is highly competitive, and the client relies on plastic manufacturing companies who acquire the secondhand shoe soles for raw materials. This ensures that his secondhand shoes are sold either way; i.e., to be worn as a good shoe or to have the soles reused. 

With the extra profits that result from this loan, Salesio shall further educate his children as well as increase the number of the rental houses that he has. The rental houses make up his secondary income source.

Salesio hopes to own a permanent building for rental houses, as he believes he is focused and hardworking.

loans.use: to add stock of secondhand shoes

loans.name: Alice Syonguma

texts.en:
Alice is married to Henry and they have three children: Rose, Isaac and Elizabeth, who are 20, 12 and 9 years old, respectively.

Alice was introduced to KADET through existing clients and this will be her first loan. She has no credit history from other Micro-Finance Institutions. She has been in the cereals and green-grocery business for six years now, and she intends to use the loan to purchase cereals like rice, beans and pigeon peas.

Alice operates within the estate where she resides and the tenants are her customers. With the extra profits she intends to expand her business further.

Alice's hopes are to run a wholesale cereals distribution company, as she believes she is focused and hardworking.

loans.use: to purchase cereals

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Chhun P., 35, is married and lives with two of her children in the Siem Reap province. She runs a grocery store, typically making $8 of profit a day. Her husband is a local doctor and he averages about $3 in profits a day. 

Chhun P. is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase rice. She will then remove the husks with the intention of reselling the rice and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to buy rice to process and resell.

loans.name: Mable Amonya

texts.en:
Mable is married to Peter and they have one child, Nelson.

Mable was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she is servicing her second loan with no previous loan history. 

Mable has a primary school which she operates as her source of business. She shall use the entire loan to renovate the classrooms of her school. Her school is located in a densely populated area with low income earners, and thus most of her students come from within the area. Mable anticipates that she will be able to make some extra profits from which she will construct a more permanent structure and use it as a school. This will upgrade the school standard. 

Mable hopes to own a secondary school. She believes she is focused and innovative.

loans.use: to renovate the classrooms of her school

loans.name: Stone Quarry Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Florence is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 31 years old and married with 4 children aged 11 to 3 years. 

Florence is a hard-working lady managing two businesses; i.e., selling clothes and stone quarrying. Although Florence has limited capital, she is able to make some profits that help her take care of her family. She is managing her businesses well because of her good customer care and the quality of her goods. 

Florence hopes to expand her business as well as to educate her children for a better future. She hopes to buy more clothes and also be able to make more stones by employing more labor to do the work.

loans.use: employ labor to make more stones and buy more clothes for her second business.

loans.name: Virginia Ngina

texts.en:
Virginia is married to Benedict and they have three children: Kennedy, Rogers and Cynthia, who are seven, three and six years old, respectively.

She was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she is servicing her third loan in KADET. Virginia has been in the green grocery business for five years, and she intends to use the loan to increase her stock, including potatoes, onions, tomatoes, green peppers and others.

She operates her business in an area occupied by low income earners who are also her customers. With the extra profit Virginia intends to educate her children. Her hopes are to expand her business so as to satisfy the community demand. She believes she is innovative and focused.

loans.use: to increase stock.

loans.name: Roseline Akinyi

texts.en:
Roseline is married to Joseph and they have four children: Reuben, Maxion, Phoebe and Jovan who are 14, 8, 5 and 2 years old, respectively.

Roseline was introduced to KADET by other already existing clients, and she is servicing her first loan with no previous credit history. 

Roseline has been in wholesale and retail shop businesses for three years. With the loan, Roseline will increase her stock of maize and wheat flour in her shop. With the extra profits, Roseline shall further the education of her children and increase the rental houses that she has put up as a side business.

Roseline hopes to own a supermarket, as she believes she is hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to increase her stock of maize and wheat flour

loans.name: Theun

texts.en: Theun C., 26, is a widow with one child and lives in the Siem Reap province. She works in a restaurant and is able to make $5 per day. However, she must also support an older sister and their mother at home. She would like to take out a loan of $500 to fix her home's leaking roof and also to build a sanitation toilet for the family.

loans.use: Fix leaking roof and build sanitation toilet

loans.name: Samet

texts.en:
Mr. Samet D. (pictured here), 51 and his wife, Mrs. Rann Ry, 50, were married in 1980 and have five children- two sons and three daughters. One of the children is married and lives outside the family home, and two are in school. The family is living in a village along National Road Number One approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Samet has been a farmer for thirty years. He grows cauliflowers. His wife has been selling fruit since 2003. She buys it from her village and transports it to sell in Phnom Penh market. Samet is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase fruit for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To purchase fruits for his wife to sell.

loans.name: Roy's Group

texts.en: Roy Z. is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a married lady with three children all in school, and she takes care of seven dependants. She has a boutique on Bugerere Road that she has been operating for 10 years and she is able to make 100,000 UGX as profits every week. This helps her to support her family, along with her husband who also helps a lot. She sells ladies’, children’s and men’s clothing and she would like to include tailoring in her offerings so that she can sell some of the clothes she makes in her boutique as well as taking orders from other customers. She needs a loan to be able to buy more clothes for her boutique.

loans.use: Buying more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kdep

texts.en: Kdep O., aged 40, is a widowed mother blessed with four children. One of her daughters is married and lives away from home, while the others are single and working. To earn a living, Kdep O. sells traditional mats that she weaves from her home. She makes the mats from palm leaf. She normally prepares a whole set of mats before selling it to her customer. She also orders and buys any mats from other weavers to serve her customer’s needs. She always waits to get orders from her customers before weaving a mat. Kdep O. requests a loan which will be used to buy a motorcycle to use as transportation and she will use any money remaining of the loan to buy more raw materials to make mats.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle and more raw materials.

loans.name: Oeung

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeung V., age 59, and her husband, Mr. Vun Kun, age 61, have been married since 1970 and have seven children: four sons and three daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, one works in a garment factory and the other one attends school. The family lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Oeung and her husband are farmers. They grow corn on their farmland in the village and hope to continue increasing the volume of their products. Therefore, Oeung is asking for a loan of $500 to pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on her farm.

loans.use: To pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey M., 45, and her husband, Mr. Pet Port, 51, have been married since 1978. They have seven children: three sons and four daughters. Three of their children are married and live in separate homes, one works in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, and the other two attend school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River. Her husband is a farmer.

Srey has been a silk weaver since she was twenty years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. She also will use a part of the loan to help provide capital for her husband’s farming business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and capital for her husband's farm

loans.name: Than

texts.en: C., age 34, is a rice farmer and married mother caring for three young children, who are studying at the secondary school. In addition, for extra income, C. also goes to fish with her husband in and around the river. C. planted her rice months ago but the crop is not growing well due to the lack of fertilizer. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to fatten her crop yield. (C. was unavailable when the photo was taken so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Yann

texts.en: Yann V. is 23 years-old and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province. She works in a grocery store, making approximately US$5 profit per day, while her husband, pictured here, is a cow dealer. He typically makes US$10 a day. The couple has two young children. Yann V. is asking for a loan of US$1200 for her husband to purchase cows to resell.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Chuch

texts.en: Chuch C., 34, is married and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province. To earn a living, she makes rice wine and raises pigs and is able to make about US $5 profit every day. Her husband is a fisherman. He catches and sells fish at the local market for US $5 a day. This couple has three school-aged children. Chuch C. would like to take out a loan of US$350 to make two investments. She will use half of the loan to purchase more pigs and the left over to replace a motorboat for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and a motorboat.

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun L. (pictured here), 53 and her husband, Mr. Vanthorn Phon, 55, have been married since 1979 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. The family is living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mrs. Thoeun L. has been selling Cambodian cake in her village for one year, while her husband has been raising pigs for three years. She is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to help her husband purchase food for pigs.

loans.use: To purchase pig food.

loans.name: Va

texts.en: Va N. is 33 years-old and resides with her husband and four of her children in Siem Reap province. She is a rice farmer and also sells cake at the local market for a profit of US$2 per day.  Her husband, pictured here, makes rice wine and raises pigs. He typically makes about US$5 profit per day. Va N. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to make two investments. She will purchase rice and remove the husks in order to resell it and make a profit and also purchase more pigs to raise.

loans.use: To purchase rice and pigs.

loans.name: Orkhan

texts.en:
Orkhan S. lives in Fuzuli region. He is single and was born in 1986.

Orkhan has been in his poultry business for two years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy turkeys and geese for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy turkeys and geese

loans.name: Sat

texts.en:
Sat P. is a good mother to three children, one of whom is married and the other two are single and no longer in school. To help contribute to the family’s daily expenses, one of her sons has a business repairing vehicles.

Sat P. owns a store along the street where she sells gasoline that she buys on credit from a gas station. Another source of family income comes from her husband, who is a taxi driver.

Sat P. is taking out her loan to build a fence around her house. She intends to use the remaining loan to buy spare parts to supply her son’s vehicle repairing business.

loans.use: To build a fence around her house and to buy spare parts for her son's business

loans.name: Crisanta

texts.en:
Crisanta S. J. comes from Jala-jala, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is a 53-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of an only child, Jomar S. J.. For her age, Crisanta is seen as strong and determined to improve their standard of living.

Crisanta operates a passenger jeepney (a small bus) and tends to a fishing business at the same time. She started these businesses only when ASHI gave her an opportunity to obtain a loan. The businesses are a big help for the family in covering their expenses and to set aside savings for the future.

The couple is requesting a loan of PhP 40,000 to pay for a radiator, brake drum, signal lights, wheels and other spare parts for the jeepney. The proceeds of her business give her money to support the immediate and basic needs of her family.

Crisanta hopes that her business will become successful someday. Along with the business success she is dreaming about, is the hope to see the graduation of her only son at college level and to see him find a stable job. She also still dreams of having a durable and concrete house of her own and to save for her family’s future.

Crisanta wants to thank ASHI and Kiva lenders who are sponsoring this loan. That is one of the greatest opportunities for her to start reaching for her goals.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for her jeepney

loans.name: Leak

texts.en:
Mr. Leak C. (pictured here), 38, and his wife, Mrs. Bunna Nao, 38, have been married since 1992 and have six children. They live on an island on Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.
Leak and his wife have been farming for 20 years. Leak doesn’t have enough capital to maintain his farm, so is therefore requesting a loan of $300 USD to purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and diesel oil.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and diesel oil

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng S. was born in 1982. She is a married woman and a humble mother caring for three young children.

Leng S. works as cleaning staff at the private school and earns a salary of $70 each month which she uses to feed her family. Her husband is a taxi driver.

Recently her husband can’t generate much income because his vehicle has often broken down and needs repair. Thus, Leng S. requested a loan to repair her husband's taxi.

loans.use: To repair her husband's taxi

loans.name: Sreyor

texts.en: Mrs. T. Sreyor and her husband, Mr. Chat Chhoeun, live in a small village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. In the past, Sreyor used to sell grocery items in her village. But, she quit this business and now runs a new business as a silk weaver. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo C. is 25 years old and lives with her husband and three of her children in Siem Reap Province. She grows vegetables and sells them at the local market, making approximately $5 USD profit a day. Her husband is a construction foreman and, on average, makes $6 USD per day. Keo C. is asking for a loan of $800 USD to purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables to sell at the market. This will help reduce her transport costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport her vegetables to market

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mrs. Yim K., 57, and her husband, Vean, 61, have jobs as local cultivators. In addition, they also fish in and around Tunle Sap Lake which is an important place for fish to be found. The couple now has four children who are still living at home and another three who are married. Two of them are employed working as massage staff in the hotel.

Recently one of her married daughters needs to live separately by building a new home, but she doesn’t have enough money to start construction. Therefore, Yim K. decided to ask for a loan of $400 which will allow her husband to build a new home.

loans.use: To build a new home for her daughter

loans.name: Tha

texts.en: Miss. Tha O. is 28 years old, single, and lives with her parents and brother and sisters in a small village along the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Tha has been weaving silk for 20 years, and learned her skill from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: 16.02.04Đông Hải Group

texts.en:
Minh Đỗ Thị (34) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Minh is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 04 Đông Hải (16.02.04 Đông Hải).
Minh is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Minh has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1,800,000 VND a month from these activities.
In 2004, Minh joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Minh is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her ninth from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. Minh plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group
1. T. Thị Mai (98) is a 32-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her food stall. 2. Lê Thị Mai (103) is a 25-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her tailoring business. 3. N. Thị Liên (114) is a 37-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock business. 4. T. Thị Hường (82) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her food stall. 5. T. Thị Lệ (29) is a 43-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her general store.

About Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Minh Đỗ Thị (34) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Minh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 04 Đông Hải (16.02.04 Đông Hải). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán thức ăn nhanh & những loại thực phẩm cao cấp khác trong cộng đồng địa phương. Minh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Minh kiếm được khoảng 1.800.000 VND. Vào 2004, Minh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Minh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 9th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. Thị Mai (98) là 32 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 2. Lê Thị Mai (103) là 25 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 3. N. Thị Liên (114) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. T. Thị Hường (82) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 5. T. Thị Lệ (29) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hel

texts.en:
Mr. Hel P., age 48, and his wife, Mrs. Kolayan Phork, age 40 and shown with him in the photo, have been married since 1990 and have three children: one son, who is assisting his parents in their farming business, and two daughters who are attending school. The family lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Hel and his wife are farmers; they grow rice and cucumbers on their farmland in the village. The couple hopes to increase the volume of their products, so Hel is asking for his first loan of $800 to pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on his farm.

loans.use: To pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Modest

texts.en:
M. Modest is a businessman who is married with six children, all of whom are in school. He lives in Namenga Kireredde in Lugazi.

Modest deals in selling electrical goods and has been in the business for over four years. He is using the loan to acquire more electrical goods such as switches, sockets, cables, bulbs, tubes, flat irons, extensions, and so forth.

Modest’s dreams are to increase his stock and run his business well and have his children study and complete university so that they can become self-reliant.

loans.use: To buy more elecrical good to sell

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun C., age 37, and her husband, Mr. Sarat Phai, age 34, live in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. One child stays at home, three attend school, and the other one is still too young.
 
Sokhoeun is a rice farmer. When she is free, she also sells fruit in the school near her house. Her husband has been operating a motor remoque taxi for two years. A remoque is a motorbike pulling a passenger trailer. 

Sokhoeun is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase fertilizer, seed and pesticide for her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seed and pesticide for her rice farm

loans.name: Teodolfa

texts.en:
Teodolfa M. is from the village of Debuloc Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 61 years old. Teodolfa is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Teodolfa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Teodolfa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Teodolfa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teodolfa is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the first loan taken out by Teodolfa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Ivy Aura

texts.en:
Ivy Aura C. is from the village of PANDUMA, TUKURAN ZAMBOANGA DEL SUR. She is 24 years old. Ivy Aura is single and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Ivy Aura owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling shampoo, candies,some snacks, toothpaste, soap (bath and laundry), sugar, etc., in the local community. Ivy Aura has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ivy Aura joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ivy Aura is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Ivy Aura from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Phiech

texts.en: Phiech S. is 20 years old and the mother of two children who live at home and attend school. Phiech S. is a local farmer: she plants various crops as well as raising many ducks to produce eggs for sale. Her husband is Mr. Eung Korng, age 26. He also uses his truck to pick up soil to sell to people who need the land to cover the polluted water surrounding their houses. Recently his truck has often broken down during the process and that affects his revenue. To solve this problem, Phiech S. decided to seek a loan to repair the broken truck of her husband.

loans.use: To repair a broken truck

loans.name: Karen Mae

texts.en:
Karen Mae C. is from the village of SAN CARLOS, TUKURAN ZAMBOANGA DEL SUR. She is 24 years old. Karen Mae is married and has 2 school-aged children. Karen Mae owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling shampoo, sugar, some food for snacks, salt and charcoal in the local community. Karen Mae has been involved in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Karen Mae joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Karen Mae is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Karen Mae from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: N. Florence is a businesswoman living in Geregere lugazi. She is married with 3 children. She owns a grocery shop. She has been in this business for over 3 years. She will use this loan to purchase shop items such as match boxes, crates of soda, soap, sugar, and so forth. She would like to increase her stock and expand the business as well. Her dream is to see her children study and complete school and then get good jobs.

loans.use: To purchase items for her grocery shop

loans.name: Lormel

texts.en:
Lormel E. is from the village of PANDUMA, TUKURAN ZAMBOANGA DEL SUR. She is 33 years old. Lormel is married and has 4 school-aged children. Lormel owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling coffee (sachet), sugar, salt, candies, shampoo and canned goods in the local community. Lormel has been involved in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Lormel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lormel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lormel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace E. is from the village of PANDUMA, TUKURAN ZAMBOANGA DEL SUR. She is 30 years old. Grace is married and has 3 school-aged children. Grace owns and operates a restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of meals to customers in the local community. Grace has been involved in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Grace joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Grace is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Grace from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en: Rashad is married and has 2 children. His family lives in the Fuzuli region. He is 32 years old and has been in this business for 3 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: M. Florence is a business lady. She is married with 3 children. The children are school going. She resides in Nakifuma and owns a hardware shop. She has been carrying out this business for over 2 years. The business is located in Nakifuma trading centre. She is using the loan in running her hardware business by stocking enough inventory (iron sheets, nails, wires, and so forth) to meet the demand of her customers. Her dream is to set up another hardware shop outlet.

loans.use: Increasing store inventory

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep S., 45, is married with four children who are no longer in school. Two of them are employed and work in restaurant, while the other two assist her with her business. She owns a small shop in her home where she sells food to her nearby neighbors. In the morning she sells porridge and in the evening she sells beef soup. She is married to Pheng, 37, a military policeman. Tep S. will use her loan to purchase a motorcycle for her family's transportation needs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Him

texts.en:
Mr. Hin K. and his wife, Mrs. Aun Doem, were married in 1983 and have eight children: three sons and five daughters. One of their children is disabled, two are garment factory workers, one son works at a brick kiln and two other children are in school. They are living along national road number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Him K. was not available for the photo, his wife is pictured instead. 

Hin and his wife are farmers, they grow rice and cucumbers. The couple hopes to increase the volume of their productivity, so Hin is applying for a loan of $400 to purchase a water pump machine to spray his farm.

loans.use: Irrigation equipment

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida A., 55, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Nestor Ogaro, they are blessed with 10 children, five of whom are already working. Having a big family, both of them make sure that they earn enough for their family’s basic needs.  She and her husband have been managing her own variety store for more than 14 years.

Adelaida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than seven years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used all the money she borrowed to buy added stocks in her variety store.   Her business lets her earn a net profit of 9,000 Philippine pesos (about $197 US) per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to get a loan of 24,000 pesos. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying additional stocks for her store.

She dreams that her three children who are still studying can ultimately graduate from college so that they too can have a better life.   

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Increasing store inventory

loans.name: Min

texts.en: Min T. is 37 years old and the father of six children who are still living at home. Two of his children are employed as staff members for a fishery association, while the others attend school. To earn a living, Min T. and his wife have their own small business as fishermen. They use many tools to fish in and around the river and are able to generate $5 each day to feed their family. Min T. lives in a very old home along the river that needs repair and he would like a $300 loan for the repairs.

loans.use: To repair his existing house

loans.name: Amgalanbayar

texts.en:
Amgalanbayar is 53 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband is unemployed. Her oldest child currently works as a dishwasher and her next two children, ages 25 and 30, are unemployed.  The youngest is a university student.

Amgalanbayar operates a small clothing production business in her town. She started her business in 2001 by renting a room at a local trading center to produce and sell her clothes. Before starting her own business operation, she worked as a dressmaker for both a state and private organizations for a while and gained much working experience during that period of time.

She has managed her business quite successfully over the years and plans to expand in the near future. She hopes to soon own her own working place. She says, "All I want is to be able to afford my children's tuition fees and help them find proper jobs." Amgalanbayar is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase fabrics and materials to make new clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics

loans.name: Febe

texts.en:
Febe P., 39, is a hard working single mom. She has one child who is in grade school and she makes sure that she earns enough for their everyday living expenses.  She has been making and selling processed food for ten years. She also directly sells clothing and silver for extra income. 

Febe has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than seven years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used almost all the money she borrowed for buying ingredients for her processed food business.   Her three current businesses let her earn a profit of PHP 29,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 43,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used as a source of added capital for her expanding business so she can buy more processed food ingredients and more clothing and silver to sell. 

She dreams that she can have her own store property for her businesses and she continues to work hard so her child can have a better future.  


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying more processed food ingredients and more clothing and silver to sell.

loans.name: Baatar

texts.en:
Baatar is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest daughter is 8 years old and attends a local secondary school while the youngest, who is 4 years old, goes to a kindergarten.

Baatar operates a wooden product making business in his town with the help of his wife. He makes a variety of wooden products such as tables, chairs and cupboards in his ger. He started his business in 1995 after graduating from his college as a craftsman. Since then he has made much progress with his business.

In order to improve his working conditions, he built a small house near his home. Baatar is very hardworking and attributes his success to his good accounting and record keeping practices. Baatar has many plans for the future of his business. He says, "I want to establish a cooperative with my friends in order to build buildings and houses." He is requesting a 620,000 tugrug (~436 USD) loan to purchase unprocessed wood.

loans.use: To purchase unprocessed wood.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane N. is a successful business woman of forty-two years. She is married with 4 children, who all go to school. She is a resident of Ndese kakakula zone. She owns a clinic and a drug shop. She will use this loan to purchase various medicines for her drug shop. Her future aim is to expand her business and establish another side business.

loans.use: To purchase various medicines for her drug shop.

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is a 41 year old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Mostafa has been working as a taxi driver since 2001. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him purchase his car for his work, since he used to rent a car for his transportation.

Mostafa is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his students, friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties. Mostafa decided on this business because he didn’t want to work for someone anymore, he wanted to have an independent work life.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his car.

loans.name: Batbuyan

texts.en:
Batbuyan is 46 years old and lives with his wife and seven children in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son, 24, attends university, her daughter, 21, is unemployed and her two sons, 16 and 19, both attend university while the youngest three are in a local secondary school.

Batbuyan operates a consumer goods retail business, with the help of his wife, in two rented stalls at a local market. They sell different kinds of consumer goods such as socks, shoes oil, soap, detergent etc. He began his business in 1998 and over the years, his business has grown and become successful. In the near future, he is planning to increase his product line and grow his customer base. Batbuyan makes iron products such as fire tongs and pots to supplement his earnings. Batbuyan is requesting a 650,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more household goods such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes, etc. for his growing business.

loans.use: To purchase more household goods such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros J., 54, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Manuel J., a driver, they are blessed with one child who is now studying in college. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her variety store for ten years.

Milagros has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used all the money she borrowed to buy added stocks for her variety store. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 11,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying additional stocks like snacks, soft drinks, and other household commodities.

She prays that her business will continue to be blessed by God so that she can support her son until he graduates from college and have a better life in the future.  

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks like snacks, soft drinks, and other household commodities.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 34 year old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Ali has owned a restaurant since 2002. He sells chicken and chicken sandwiches. Ali requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase chicken for his restaurant. This is his fourth cycle and he has always paid on time. His previous loans helped improve his work by enlarging his restaurant and offering new platters.
